headline: Turkey and Dumplings
description: This variation on classic, homey, and comforting chicken and dumplings makes use of leftover turkey and features light and fluffy biscuit-based dumplings.
name: Turkey and Dumplings
recipeIngredient: 3 tablespoons plus 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, divided
1 1/2 quarts (48 ounces) homemade or store-bought low sodium chicken broth
3 medium ribs celery, chopped medium (about 1 1/2 cups)
1 pound leftover roast turkey, torn into rough bite-sized pieces (see note)
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: In a large Dutch oven, heat 3 tablespoons (45g) butter over medium-high heat until melted. Add 3 tablespoons (24g) flour and cook, stirring constantly, until pale golden brown, about 3 minutes. Slowly whisk in broth. Add gravy, if using, along with onions, carrots, and celery. Bring to a simmer and cook, stirring occasionally, until vegetables are softened, about 10 minutes. Stir in turkey, peas, and half of parsley, and season to taste with pepper and 1 1/2 teaspoons salt. Remove from heat.

Melt remaining 3 tablespoons (45g) butter. In a medium bowl, stir together remaining 1 1/2 cups (192g) flour, baking powder, chives, remaining parsley, and remaining 3/4 teaspoon salt. In a second bowl, whisk together buttermilk, egg, and melted butter in a second bowl. Pour buttermilk mixture over flour mixture and stir with a wooden spoon until it forms a shaggy dough.

Return stew to a bare simmer. Using a tablespoon measure, drop dumpling dough in 1-inch balls over surface of stew. Cover and cook until dumplings have puffed, feel firm to the touch, and a toothpick inserted in center of one comes out clean, about 15 minutes. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody:
It came out very well indeed! Everyone enjoyed this hearty, turkey dish with the moist but fluffy dumplings. The dumplings are really a sort of miracle.... both tender and fluffy! 
Living in Toronto, I know how minor climate conditions can affect risen dumplings, so I looked at all the notes of contributors, and I made one substitution: instead of 1/2 tsp baking powder, I used 1 tsp. baking powder and 1/4 teaspoon baking soda. That did the trick!
Otherwise, I followed the recipe by the letter.
Rather than calling it an "old recipe", I think that we should just call it a classic.
Created an account just to pop in and say how amazing this was. Used some kind of ruined turkey, mostly dark meat, and everything was phenomenal. The real comfort food

I really want to try this. (I saw an orange leaf fall from one of our Norway maples today, so it's soup time!). Has anyone come to a conclusion re: whether the 1/2 tsp of baking powder indicated in the recipe is correct? There seems to be some disagreement.

@alvinsingh I think that the milk substitution was the likely culprit. If you can't get buttermilk or kefir (and kefir is a perfect substitution), then the next best thing is to sour your milk in some other way (lemon juice, vinegar, some yogurt). I am making this right now and we'll see how it comes out.

I know this is a pretty old recipe but just made it for the first time. While the soup part is great, the dumplings where tough. Very little expansion despite cooking for 20 minutes.

I used milk instead of buttermilk, maybe that's what did it?
